title: 'I Have A Needle In The Same Pocket That Has Treats' Vet's Post About Euthanasia Will Move You
text:
'I Have A Needle In The Same Pocket That Has Treats' Vet's Post About Euthanasia Will Move You

'I Have A Needle In The Same Pocket That Has Treats' Vet's Post About Euthanasia Will Move You

Losing a pet can be a heartbreaking experience and especially so for pet owners for whom they have become an integral and irreplaceable part of the family.

The emotional toll of euthanizing animals is shared equally by the owner and the veterinarians, and that's what the following post explains.

Twitter

Brenda Gough from Burford, Ontario penned an emotional Facebook post, explaining how the vets feel when pushing the needle on a pet that cannot be saved.

The post reads, 'I want her to live forever for you. I want that so badly it hurts. I feel like I have failed him and you when I have run out of options to keep them, and you, comfortable and happy.'

'I have the needle in the pocket of my white coat. The same pocket that was always full of treats for him.'

'I put my stethoscope to her heart to make sure it has stopped but she is held so tight to your chest that maybe that is your heart I hear pounding or maybe it’s mine and all the blood rushing through my ears as I try so so so hard not to turn into a blubbering mess,' reads the heartbreaking post.

Things are harder for vets because more often than not owners don't want see their beloved pets breathing their last, so the last moments of the pet are spent frantically looking for their owners.

In an interview with the Bored Panda, Brenda revealed that she carries out one or two euthanasia every week and that it's so emotionally taxing that she's literally needs to take time off work after it.

She also says that suicide rates are extremely high among veterinarians and veterinary caregivers for this very reason.
